Hey folks. So I have seens these expressions all over the place in julia code, in particular in the flux tutorials and also in some diffeq code, but I am not sure why they are used or what the full explicit syntax would otherwise be. So in the Flux tutorial there is an expression like
``` gradient(()->y(x), params([W, b]))```
Where there is this `() -> `, syntax. The julia docs call these zero-argument anonymous funtions, and I understand what anonymous functions are. But I was not clear why there is an empty tuple, etc. This is one of those things that I have never payed attention to in passing, but I figured I should now actually try and understand why and when to use zero argument anonymous functions with this syntax.

text:
`f = x -> 2`  f has one argument, x
`f = () -> 2`  f has no arguments
`f = (x, y) -> 2`  f has 2 arguments, x and y
`f = x, y -> 2`  invalid syntax
`f = -> 2`  invalid syntax

`2` is just the body of the function. so, all of these functions just return 2

text: It’s probably also helpful to go with the intuition that tuples are abstraction of function arguments in Julia. So an empty tuple maps to a zero-argument function quite naturally under this design.
